journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: On a structural–acoustic panel cavity modelling in the mid-high frequency domain

article-meta.aff: 1Laboratory of Tribology and Systems Dynamics, UMR CNRS 5513, Ecole Centrale de Lyon - LTDS, Ecully, France
2Missile Structural Analysis Department, EADS Astrium ST, Les Mureaux, France

author-notes.corresp: *Laboratory of Tribology and Systems Dynamics, UMR CNRS 5513, Ecole Centrale de Lyon - LTDS, Ecully, France. email: mohamed.ichchou@ec-lyon.fr

abstract.p: This article presents a fluid–structure interaction modelling, based on a coupling between component mode synthesis or finite element and statistical energy analysis (SEA). The hybrid strategy is applied on a panel–cavity coupled system using a modal analysis with uncoupled modes of the subsystems and through a finite element model of the coupled system. The determination of the energy transfer parameters is then considered. The hybrid SEA model is then validated in the high-frequency domain by comparison with an SEA model. Finally, a parametric survey is offered through the established modelling and conclusions on its validity domain are drawn.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: In the mid-high frequency domain, the behaviour of mechanical systems is very sensitive to uncertainties. Averaged methods like statistical energy analysis (SEA) are therefore often considered specifically in the high frequency range. Furthermore, the systems being represented with scalar global energetic variables, SEA and other energy methods are more convenient than FEM or modal analysis in the mid-high frequency domain. Indeed, the great number of degree of freedom or system modes needed to get accurate results leads to prohibitive calculation time.

However, the applicability of SEA is often limited, particularly when the modal overlap of the system is low [1]. Moreover, SEA cannot deal efficiently with heterogeneous coupling configurations, precisely: coupling between stiff and flexible structural parts for instance. This effect is also considered to be a mid-frequency situation [2]. For instance, structural–acoustic coupled systems can, in some cases, present such a profile. Indeed, the behaviour of the structure can present low-frequency characteristics, whereas the behaviour of the fluid part has mid- or high-frequency features. This makes the wide frequency band numerical modelling of such a structural–acoustic problem delicate even when pure analytical basis is feasible [3]. In this article, the panel cavity-coupled structural acoustics is further considered. This example is often used in benchmarks studies by the vibroacoustic community (see for instance references [3–6] among others). Most of the phenomena that can be handled for complex geometries are explicitly included in this benchmark example.

Several authors have investigated the fluid–structure interaction treatment in the mid- and high-frequency domains. Most of the proposed works are based on a reduced modal analysis of the system. In the high-frequency domain, fluid–structure interaction can be modelled with SEA [7]. The radiation coefficient of the structure is, in this case, employed in order to complete the energy balance associated to structural–acoustic coupling. Peretti and Dowell modelled a panel–cavity coupled system using Asymptotic Modal Analysis (AMA) modelling and gave an energetic description of the coupled system based on a reduced model derived from a classical modal description of the system [4]. The authors showed that the modelling of a panel–cavity coupled system using the uncoupled modes of the subsystem converged to the SEA results in the high-frequency domain and could be used in a frequency domain larger than the frequency band covered by SEA. In the mid-frequency domain, Pan et al. [3, 5, 8] provided very interesting insights into the panel cavity generic system. Indeed, Pan et al. gave an energetic description of a panel–cavity coupled system considering the modes of each uncoupled subsystem. Neglecting the cross-modal terms in the expression of the velocity of the panel and the pressure in the cavity, they simplified the modal analysis on the coupled system and gave an accurate energetic description of the coupled system in mid-frequency for cavity and panel point excitations.

In this article, the work published by Pan et al. is extended in the context of recently published mid-high frequency tentatives. Indeed, a panel–cavity coupled system is considered using a hybrid FEM/SEA method: the hybrid SEA method. This method, which is derived from the SEA way of thinking, was studied by Fredo and Mace [1, 9–11] and applied to structural systems mainly. Fredo applied the hybrid SEA method to an L-shaped plate. In reference [1], Mace gave a general formulation for structural hybrid SEA coefficients and studied the frequency and spatial coupling parts of the hybrid SEA coefficients for different frequency ranges. However, hybrid SEA has not been applied yet to a fluid–structure coupled system. The purpose of the present contribution is to check the hybrid SEA formulation, established by Mace [1, 11], feasibility for structural–acoustic problems and to verify its robustness through a parametric survey. The accuracy and efficiency of hybrid SEA depend on the modal expansion used in the fluid–structure system treatment. Several modal expansions are used in this article to calculate the hybrid SEA matrix of the panel–cavity coupled system. In Section 2.3, the hybrid SEA matrix is calculated with the uncoupled subsystem modal basis. The obtained expression is then validated in the high-frequency domain, Section 3, by comparing it to a classical SEA model. A second formulation through an FEM model of the fluid–structure coupled system in order to evaluate the hybrid SEA matrix is then proposed. Finally, a weak- and a strong-coupled system are considered with the different computed formulations. The study of the formulations accuracy in several coupling strength is analysed.

sec.title: 2 HYBRID SEA MODEL OF THE COUPLED PANEL–CAVITY SYSTEM
2.1 Hybrid SEA approach issues
sec.p: High-frequency hybrid methods, often, consist of estimating the energy matrix and using the inverse energetic approach to estimate the coupling loss factors between considered subsystems. These approaches involve a classic SEA hypothesis on the strength of coupling between subsystems. In order to ensure good conditioning of the energy matrix, subsystems need to be weakly coupled. In the case of mid-frequency applications, subsystems can be strongly coupled and proper SEA analysis thus fails. Some authors have shown that, in the mid-frequency range, the indirect coupling loss factors have to be taken into account to express the energetic relationship between subsystems. The power flow includes indirect coupling and it can be shown that coupling parameters are strongly dependent on the damping of the given structures. It appears that, in this case, the energetic relationship between total mean energies of the subsystems and the power injected in subsystems would be more appropriately written as follows (1) Coupling loss factors and internal loss factors are not explicitly expressed and the total mean energies are directly obtained from the previous relation. This implicitly requires that the matrix of the energy influence coefficients, obtained from a finite element or a component mode synthesis (CMS) analysis, be determined from good estimates of structural damping. The energy influence coefficient can be directly obtained from total mean energies of the subsystems, averaged in space and frequency, normalized by the power injected into subsystems. Energies are obtained from classic FEM codes or through CMS which provide the vibrating displacements in the considered subsystem. The computation of such energy influence coefficients is thus the main issue in the hybrid SEA model definition. In what follows this question is considered in the case of fluid–structure coupling.

sec.title: 2.2 Hybrid SEA formulation for the coupled panel–cavity system
sec.p:
The system studied here is a flexible panel coupled with a rectangular cavity filled with air (Fig. 1). Fig. 1
Panel–cavity coupled system

The coupled system is subdivided in two subsystems: the panel and the cavity. The hybrid SEA matrix of the coupled system is a 2-by-2 matrix and expresses the averaged energies in terms of input power in each subsystem, as shown in equation (2) (2) In reference [1], Mace offered a general formulation for the hybrid SEA coefficients. The excitation of each subsystem has a rain-on-the-roof format (random and spatially delta-correlated, the spectral density being frequency independent). Excitations of different subsystems are considered to be uncorrelated. In reference [1], Mace introduces additional assumptions on the modal behaviour of the system to be dealt within order to simplify the calculation: the modes were assumed to have equal bandwidth and only the resonant modes were taken in account in the response of the system. The hybrid SEA coefficient between subsystem s and a was thus expressed as follows (3) where ωη is the modal bandwidth and Ψjk (s) the cross-mode participation factor (4) where ρ being the mass density in subsystem s, Φj, and Φk the jth and kth deformed shapes of the coupled system. Γjk depends on the natural frequencies and bandwidth of the jth and kth modes of the coupled system. Γjk increases when modes j and k are excited and when their natural frequencies are close to each other.

In the next paragraph, the hybrid SEA coefficients of the panel–cavity coupled system are derived using two different approaches. The formulation based on the uncoupled modes is first considered. An hybrid SEA derivation based on a finite element model of the coupled system is presented in Section 3.

sec.title: 2.3 Hybrid SEA based on uncoupled subsystem modes
sec.p: In what follows, the flexible panel is described by its normal velocity v(x, y; ω) and the cavity filled with air by the pressure p(x, y, z; ω).The dimensions of the system are a × b × c, as shown in Fig. 1. The following notations are used here: ρ0 and c0 for the air density and speed of sound in air, and ρs, hs, D, and As for the density, thickness, bending stiffness, and area of the panel. The expression of the hybrid SEA matrix is determined exciting both subsystems with a rain-on-the-roof disturbance.

The modal basis used here is the simply supported structural modes Φm s and the rigid cavity modes Φn a, which are expressed analytically. The modal equation of a panel–cavity coupled system excited with an acoustic source is well described in reference [8]. This equation is expressed as follows (5) where V and P are the panel modal velocity and the cavity modal pressure, respectively, χs a diagonal matrix corresponding to the transfer matrix of the uncoupled panel (6) χa is a diagonal matrix corresponding to the transfer matrix of the uncoupled cavity (7) where ωsm and ωan are the natural modal pulsations of Φm s and Φn a, respectively. Mm s and Mn a are the modal mass of the panel and the cavity and are given by: Mm s=ρshs∫As(Φm s)2ds and Mn a=ρ0∫V(Φn a)2dV. Expressions for the modal characteristics can be found in reference [8]. F is the generalized force vector applied on the coupled system. When the panel is excited with a pressure pext(x, y; ω), F can be written as (8) where (9) When the cavity is excited with a sound source described by its volume velocity qa(x, y, z; ω), F can be written (10) where (11) B is the modal coupling matrix between the panel and the cavity (12) The panel is now excited with a rain-on-the-roof excitation (Qa = 0 in equation (5)). Two hybrid SEA coefficients can be expressed from equation (2) (13) (14) Calculating the SEA matrix, Lyon [7] makes the assumption that the frequency-averaged kinetic and potential energies are considered to be equal to each other. In order to minimize the assumptions in the hybrid SEA model and considering that the hybrid SEA method may be applied in mid-frequency, this assumption is not used here. Thus, both energies are considered in the calculation of the averaged panel energy. (15) where ρs, hs, D, and As are the density, thickness, bending stiffness, and area of the panel, Spext the power spectral density of the excitation, and Hss the transfer matrix of the coupled panel: Hss = (χs+tB χa -1B)-1χs. The averaged energy in the cavity is also calculated from the kinetic and potential acoustic energy (16) where Has is the transfer matrix of the coupled cavity: Has=χa -1B(χs+tBχa -1B)-1χs. Finally, the injected power in the panel is expressed as follows (17) Assuming that Spext(ω) = 1 in all the frequency range of interest, equations (15), (16), and (17) lead to the expression of structural–structural and acoustical–structural hybrid SEA coefficients Ass and Aas (18) (19)

The cavity is now excited with a space and frequency uncorrelated excitation qext(x, y, z; ω). The rain-on-the-roof excitation is modelled here from a superposition of several monopole excitations of the cavity, randomly spread into the cavity. Asa and Aaa can thus not be expressed analytically. Both structural–acoustical and acoustical–acoustical coefficients are calculated from equation (2),where Pinj,s = 0 is stated (20) (21) The energies and injected powers in the cavity are calculated for five monopole excitations spread randomly in the cavity, in order to simulate the delta-correlated excitation. The energies and injected powers for each excitation are then averaged in space and frequency and finally averaged on the excitations to lead to the hybrid SEA coefficients. For a sake of clarity, details on the averaged energies and injected powers calculation are not included in this article. Further details and comments are included in Appendix.

sec.title: 3 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sec.p: The panel–cavity coupled system is often studied in the literature [3–6, 8, 12]. This generic situation can be extended to many industrial applications [8]. Under some assumptions, such as weak coupling, this configuration can be dealt with efficiently with uncoupled modes of each subsystem [12]. In Section 2, hybrid SEA has been applied to a panel–cavity coupled system described with the uncoupled modes of each subsystem. Coupling between panel modes and cavity modes can have an impact on the energetic behaviour of the coupled system.Some aspects of fluid–structure coupling influence on the hybrid SEA model are detailed in this section. First, the hybrid SEA model of the coupled system is compared with an SEA model of the panel–cavity coupled system in order to discuss the high-frequency validity of the hybrid SEA model. Then, an hybrid SEA matrix of the coupled system is calculated from an FEM model of the system. Some aspects of fluid–structure coupling influence on the hybrid SEA model are described in detail in this section. Finally, hybrid SEA model based on uncoupled modes is compared with hybrid SEA model based on FEM for a strong coupling strength between panel and cavity. The numerical test cases used in reference [12] are employed in the what follows for comparisons and extensions purposes.

sec.title: 3.1 Validation of the hybrid SEA method based on uncoupled modes
sec.p: The system considered here is an aluminium panel coupled with a cavity filled with air. This coupled system was studied in references [5, 8]. The thickness, modal density, and Young's modulus of the panel are, respectively, 5.8 mm, 7800 kg/m3, and 6.9×1010 Pa. The characteristics of the fluid are those of the air (under pressure and temperature standard conditions). The reverberation times in the panel and the cavity – defining the damping in the subsystems – are, respectively, Ts = 0.4 s and Ta = 1 s. With these characteristics, if the Schroeder frequency is considered as the limit frequency between mid- and high-frequency – which corresponds to the overlap of four to five modes in the cavity – the high-frequency domain starts at 2000 Hz. The limit between low- and mid-frequency has been stated rigorously by Pan [3] and corresponds to a modal overlap M = 0.5 (i.e. when two modes in the cavity overlap).

Figure 2 presents the energy influence coefficients (EIC) matrix calculated with two methods: hybrid SEA and SEA. In the high-frequency domain, the EIC calculated with hybrid SEA and the EIC calculated with SEA are in good agreement. In SEA calculations, the observed behaviour around 2110 Hz corresponds to the maximum radiation of the panel into the cavity. The hybrid SEA model do not present such a behaviour. In the low-frequency region however, below 800 Hz, hybrid SEA prediction presents significant oscillations, unlike SEA. Those discrepancies are mainly due to the limitation of SEA method in the low-frequency domain. The hybrid SEA method can therefore be considered as an extension of the SEA validity domain in the low-frequency domain. Fig. 2
Hybrid SEA (−) and SEA (−−) energy influence coefficients of the coupled system: s, panel; a, cavity

In references [1, 11], the modes of the whole system were used for the hybrid SEA calculation. The system was first analysed globally. The different subsystems were then introduced for the expression of the hybrid SEA calculation. An approach similar to what was used in references [1, 11] is employed hereinafter to obtain a reference calculation of the hybrid SEA coefficients calculated in Section 2.3. FEM analysis is used to calculate the averaged energies and injected powers for different excitations of the panel and the cavity. Precisely, five excitations on the panel, corresponding to point forces spread randomly on the panel, and five excitations on the cavity, corresponding to monopole acoustic source located randomly in the cavity are considered. The energies and injected powers are then averaged with respect to the studied excitation locations and in frequency. The average energies and injected powers are finally used to obtain the hybrid SEA coefficients. Figure 3 presents the hybrid SEA coefficients calculated with the first method presented in this article, namely the one using the uncoupled modes of each subsystem and ones calculated using full FEM analysis. Both predictions are in good agreement. Some discrepancies are however present. These differences are the consequence of assumptions and simplifications made in the modal approach of hybrid SEA. Specifically, modes used are the sub system uncoupled ones. This modal analysis gives a pertinent description of the system in terms of energy in the subsystems. However, the pressure is not accurately calculated in the whole cavity, particularly near the panel. Therefore, using subsystems uncoupled modes leads to some inaccuracies in the structural acoustic interaction process. In what follows, the hybrid SEA model obtained from FEM which is unsimplified compared to the uncoupled modal one is mostly used as a reference. A number of parametric studies are offered in what follows for hybrid SEA robustness issues mainly. Precisely, the cross-coupling effects, the resonant modes and coincident ones as well as the structural–acoustic coupling strength are among the numerically considered factors. Fig. 3
Hybrid SEA EIC calculated with uncoupled modes of each subsystem (−) and FEM model of the coupled system (−−)

sec.title: 3.2 Analysis of the hybrid SEA modelling based on the uncoupled modes
sec.p: The hybrid SEA model based on the uncoupled modes of the simply supported panel and the rigid cavity, provides a pertinent way to study the fluid–structure coupling. First, the modes are known analytically; therefore, the coupling can be analysed in detail. Then, several simplifications can be made on the hybrid SEA model by simply reducing either the panel modal basis or the cavity modal base.

sec.title: 3.2.1 Panel and acoustic cross-coupling effects
sec.p: In mid-high frequency analysis, the inter-coupling between panel modes or the inter-coupling between cavity modes (structural or acoustic cross-coupling) is often neglected [4, 5]. Indeed, in case of weak coupling, the influence of panel mode shapes on a particular panel mode can be neglected compared to the contribution of the cavity modes through the fluid–structure coupling. In addition, spatial and frequency average tends to increase the cross-coupling insignificance [11]. The simplifications concerning cross-coupling made in reference [5] are considered in this section: structural cross-coupling is neglected in the panel response while acoustic cross-coupling is neglected in the cavity response: the modal transfer matrix Hss, Has, Hsa, and Haa of the coupled panel and cavity are considered as diagonal.

Figures 4 and 5 show the hybrid SEA coefficients calculated with the cross-coupling assumption compared to the original modal hybrid SEA coefficients. Both estimations are in agreement. Slight discrepancies can be observed in the mid-low frequency range for the hybrid SEA coupling coefficients Aas and Asa. In reference [12], Sum and Pan studied the mechanisms involved in the structure and acoustic cross-coupling. They put in evidence that the error due to negligence of panel cross-coupling of the calculation of the velocity in the panel is larger in case of cavity excitation than panel excitation: the panel modes are coupled through the cavity modes, which are more energetic when the cavity is directly excited. The cross-coupling contribution is then more important in the hybrid SEA coupling coefficients. Fig. 4
Hybrid SEA EIC Ass and Aas calculated with the modal method: with cross–coupling (−) and without cross-coupling (−−) Fig. 5
Hybrid SEA EIC Asa and Aaa calculated with the modal method: with cross–coupling (−) and without cross-coupling (−−)

sec.title: 3.2.2 Influence of resonant modes and coincident modes
sec.p:
The hybrid SEA matrix is calculated here using two reductions of the panel modal basis : a basis containing the resonant modes of the panel or a basis containing both the resonant modes and the coincident modes (Fig. 6). A panel mode is considered as resonant if its resonant frequency is located in the 3-dB frequency band around the excited frequency. A mode is coincident if its panel wavenumber is equal to the acoustic wavenumber k = ω/c0. In this case, the modal radiation efficiency calculated for a panel radiating in an open space is maximum [13]. In Fig. 6, the coefficients calculated with a reduced panel modal basis are in good agreement with the coefficients calculated with the complete modal base. Fig. 6
Hybrid SEA EIC calculated with a reduced modal basis of the panel containing the resonant modes only (−−), and the resonant modes and the modes with a strong radiation efficiency (−.−) - hybrid SEA EIC calculated with the complete modal basis (−)

sec.title: 3.2.3 Panel–cavity coupling strength
sec.p:
The panel–cavity coupled system presented in Section 2.3 is a weak coupled system: the system modes are very similar to the uncoupled panel and cavity modes (Table 1). Therefore, the reduction used in the hybrid SEA calculation based on the uncoupled modes of the subsystems gives a good approximation of the energy behaviour of the panel–cavity coupled system. Table 1
Ten first coupled and uncoupled modes for the weakly coupled system (Hz)

Panel modes Uncoupled Coupled Cavity modes Uncoupled Coupled

(1,2) 60.71 60.05 (0,1,0) 149.13 149.47
(2,1) 84.64 83.92 (0,0,1) 171.50 171.50
(1,3) 113.55 112.87 (1,0,0) 197.58 196.07

(3,1) 177.51 178.23 (1,0,1) 261.63 262.03
(1,4) 187.67 186.81 (0,2,0) 298.26 298.86
(3,2) 209.32 208.14 (1,1,1) 301.15 301.51
(2,4) 243.54 241.72 (0,0,2) 343.00 343.60

Here, another coupled panel–cavity system is studied, where the coupling between the panel and the cavity is strong. This coupled system was previously studied by Hong and Kim [12] and is composed of a 1 × 0.5 × 0.002 m panel coupled with a 1 × 0.5 × 0.66 m cavity. The panel is an aluminium panel, with a Young's modulus Es = 7.1010. The characteristics of the acoustical fluid are ρ0 = 6.04 kg.m3 and c0 = 162.9 m/s. The panel is excited with a point force located at (x = 0.71 m, y = 0.30 m). Table 2 compares the uncoupled and coupled modes for each subsystem. Unlike the first coupled system, the coupled modal frequencies of this second coupled system are very different from the uncoupled modal frequencies. The analysis of the modal frequencies and mode shapes of coupled and uncoupled subsystems show that the panel and the cavity are strongly coupled. Table 2
Ten first coupled and uncoupled modes for the strongly coupled system (Hz)
Panel-controlled modes Cavity-controlled modes
Panel modes Uncoupled Coupled Cavity modes Uncoupled Coupled
(1,1) 24.21 32.78 (0,0,0) 0 0
(2,1) 38.73 34.20 (1,0,0) 81.45 83.12

(4,2) 154.99 147.99 (2,0,1) 203.63 203.52
(1,3) 179.22 176.39 (1,1,1) 219.32 221.80

Figure 7 presents the EIC in each sub system calculated with both hybrid SEA method and SEA. The SEA coefficients are very similar to the hybrid SEA coefficients calculated with a modal analysis. On the contrary, the hybrid SEA coefficients calculated with FEM – which is the reference result here – are higher than for hybrid SEA based on modal analysis or SEA. It is well known that SEA is not accurate for strong coupled system, which is shown here by the discrepancy between SEA and hybrid SEA based on FEM. hybrid SEA based on a modal analysis is not accurate either when applied to the strong coupled system: the reduction used for this hybrid SEA model is not accurate enough for strong coupled system. Fig. 7
Hybrid SEA EIC calculated with modal analysis and FEM for strongly coupled system compared to SEA EIC, (−) : hybrid SEA (modal analysis), (−−) : hybrid SEA (FEM), (−.−) : SEA

sec.title: 4 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p:
This article describes an hybrid SEA model of a panel–cavity coupled system. The energy matrix derivation is based on a modal analysis using uncoupled subsystems modes. The hybrid SEA model was validated in the high-frequency domain by a comparison with an SEA model. Some simplifications were made on the modal basis used to calculate the hybrid SEA matrix of the coupled system. Those simplifications improved the calculation time of the hybrid SEA matrix without lost in the accuracy, specifically in the mid-high frequency domain. Ultimately, a parametric survey was investigated using the established model. The main conclusions drawn are as follows.
In case of weak coupling, a slight improvement in the calculation time could be reached by neglecting either structural or acoustic cross-coupling.
As in SEA calculation, the panel modal basis was reduced by neglecting the non-resonant modes. It was shown that the reduced model and the reference model were in good agreement. When the coincident panel modes are added to the modal basis, the accuracy of hybrid SEA calculation is not significantly improved.
In case of strong coupling, it was shown that the hybrid SEA method based on uncoupled modes cannot give an accurate description of the system compared to the hybrid SEA method based on FEM. The modal basis used on the modal hybrid SEA method must therefore be improved for an accurate modelling of strong coupled systems. Further developments are in progress and in particular the transient dynamic issues associated to specific excitations launchers are facing [14, 15]. It should be also noticed that most of the paper finding are under implementation within SEALASCAR, which is daily employed in EADS Astrium.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This work was supported by EADS Astrium.

sec.title: Modal equations of the coupled structural–acoustic system
sec.p: The modal equations of a panel–cavity coupled system excited with an acoustic source can be found in reference [8]. The equations of the system are projected on the modes of each uncoupled subsystem. The simply supported panel modes (22) with the corresponding modal frequency (23) The rigid cavity modes are (24) with the corresponding modal frequency (25) The equation of the panel is based on Kirchhoff's theory (26) where v is the normal velocity of the panel, L the linear differential operator of elasticity of the panel, pext the pressure exciting the panel, and p the pressure in the cavity.
Using the modal expressions of the normal velocity of the panel and the pressure in the cavity, equation (26) is projected on the panel mode Φr s (27) where v=∑VmΦm s and p=∑PnΦn a.

The modal mass of the panel Mm s=ρshs∫AsΦm sΦm sds=ρshsAs/4 and the coupling matrix B between the panel and the cavity are introduced (28) Using the property of orthogonality of the panel modes, equation (27) becomes (29) Finally, a modal damping ηsm is introduced in equation (29), leading to the modal expression of the coupled panel equation (30) The modal equation of the pressure p in the cavity is based on Helmholtz equation (31) with the following boundary conditions
On the rigid boundaries (32)
On the flexible panel (33)
Helmoholtz equation is applied on the cavity mode Φa n (34) with the following boundary condition (35) Green's function is applied on equations (31) and (33) (36) The modal mass of the cavity Mn a=ρ0∫VΦn aΦn adV=ρ0V(12)(3-δ(m,0)-δ(n,0)-δ(t,0)) is introduced, where δ is the Kronecker delta. Using the modal expression of the velocity v of the panel and the pressure p in the cavity along with the orthogonality properties on the panel and the cavity modes, equation (36) becomes: (37) As for the panel, the modal damping of the cavity ηan is introduced, which leads to the modal expression of the coupled cavity equation (38) equations (30) and (38) lead to the modal equations of the coupled system (39) where χs is a diagonal matrix corresponding to the transfer matrix of the uncoupled panel (40) χa is a diagonal matrix corresponding to the transfer matrix of the uncoupled cavity (41) and Qs is the generalized forces vector on the panel: (42)

sec.title: Averaged energies in the coupled system for a rain-on-the-roof excitation of the panel
Averaged energy in the panel
sec.p: The panel being excited, the generalised forces vector F in equation (5) is expressed with equation 8. The modal velocity is then (43) The panel being excited with a rain-on-the-roof excitation, the pressure field pext on the panel must fit the following condition (44) where the joint acceptance between panel modes p and q is given by (45) The generalized force vector Qs can therefore be rewritten as follows (46) Introducing the coupled transfer matrix of the panel Hss, equation 43 becomes (47) The kinetic energy Ecs is given by (48) and the potential energy Eps is given by (49) The space and frequency averaged energy in the panel is then (50) Using the expression of the modal velocity given by equation (47), equation (50) becomes (51) where Ψ~m s=∫As(Φm s(x,y))2dxdy.

sec.title: Averaged energy in the cavity
sec.p: The averaged energy in the cavity is calculated from the modal pressure Pn. From equation (5), the modal pressure vector is (52) Using the assumption of ‘rain-on-the-roof’ excitation on the panel (given in equation (46)), equation (52) becomes (53) The expression of the energy in the cavity is calculated from the kinetic and potential pressure energy (54) (55) which gives (56) Using the expression of the modal pressure from equation (53), the final expression of the energy in the cavity is (57) where Ψ~n a=∫V(Φn a(x,y,z))2dxdydz.

sec.title: Injected power in the panel
sec.p: The expression of the injected power in the panel is (58) Using the modal expression of the normal velocity v of the panel and the pressure field pext, the expression of the injected power can be reformulated in (59) Using the rain-on-the-roof assumption, equation (59) becomes (60) Finally the expression of the averaged injected power in the panel is (61)

sec.title: Averaged energies and input power in the coupled system for a point source excitation in the cavity
Averaged energy in the panel
sec.p: Let us consider a monopole source qa in the cavity, located at the point (xa, ya, za) of the cavity.

The modal equation of the coupled system when the cavity is excited is (62) Introducing the transfer matrix between the coupled panel and the cavity (63) the modal velocity vector for the panel becomes (64) The averaged energy of the panel for a monopole excitation of the cavity is obtained when this expression is used in equation (50).

sec.title: Averaged energy and injected power in the cavity
sec.p: Introducing the transfer matrix of the coupled cavity Haa, the modal pressure vector for the cavity is (65) The averaged energy in the cavity for a monopole excitation is obtained introducing this expression in equation (56).

The injected power in the cavity is calculated for each monopole excitation with the integration of the acoustic flow on a surface S surrounding the monopole source (66) The integration of the power flow is calculated numerically with a Riemann integral.
